abstract: This work aimed to investigate effects of the ocean contamination by the sunscreen Benzophenone-3 (BP3) and acidification, caused by CO 2 enrichment, to the yellow clam, Amarilladesma mactroides. Biochemical biomarkers were analyzed in tissues (gills, digestive gland, and mantle) of clams exposed to the environmental concentration of 1 μg/L BP3, at seawater natural pH (pH 8.1) and at lower pH (pH 7.6). The tissues responded in different ways considering their physiological roles. In general, BP3 altered activity of the enzymes, glutathione-S-transferase (GST) and glutathione cysteine ligase (GCL); but mostly increased the level of glutathione (GSH). These effects were enhanced by acidification, without augmenting lipid peroxidation (LPO). Carbonic anhydrase activity (CA) increased after BP3 exposure in the digestive gland and decreased in the gills at pH 7.6, while Ca 2+-ATPase activity was affected by acidification only. Changing levels of these enzymes can alter shell formation and affect the bivalve maintenance in impacted environments.

body_text.text: Ultraviolet (UV) radiation filters are compounds present in sunscreens and other personal care products to protect the skin from solar radiation. Among these compounds, Benzophenone-3 (BP3), also known as oxybenzone (2-hydroxyl-4-methoxybenzophenone) is commonly used. BP3 reaches aquatic environments through direct inputs as removal from skin in recreation activities, and indirect inputs that include releases from wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs), unable to remove BP3 from domestic effluents which, in turn, achieve the oceans as final destination. This compound has been widely detected in bodies of water, biota, and sediment (Tashiro and Kameda, 2013; Tsui et al., 2014; Gago-Ferrero et al., 2015; Sharifan et al., 2016; Peng et al., 2017) . In seawater, the environmental concentration of BP3 ranges from 0.1 μg/L to 5.4 μg/L Tsui et al., 2014; Ramos et al., 2015) . BP3 is a chemical of environmental concern due to the low degradability in aquatic environments and because it has capacity for being accumulated by organisms, mainly in lipophilic tissues (Log Kow 3.79) (Rodil et al., 2009; Gago-Ferrero et al., 2012; Vione et al., 2013; . Sang and Leung (2016) calculated the risk quotient (RQ) for BP3 as 2.60 and indicated that this UV filter may pose significant risks to the marine aquatic ecosystems.

There are some reports on the toxicity of BP3 to aquatic organisms. Studies have shown that sublethal doses of BP3 are related to endocrine disorders in fish (Coronado et al., 2008; and cause alterations in the antioxidant mechanisms (Gao et al., 2013; Liu et al., 2015) . In addition, BP3 is harmful to corals, causing malformations in larvae and increasing bleaching rates (Downs et al., 2016; He et al., 2019) . As a result, there are locations (e.g. Pacific archipelago of Palau and Hawaii, USA) that have banned the commercialization and use of sunscreens containing BP3 (Republic of Palau, 2018; Hawaii State Legislature, 2018) . Despite the growing studies evaluating the detrimental effects of BP3 on aquatic biota, its use is allowed in vast majority of countries.

In addition to contamination, another factor that affects marine environments is the acidification of the oceans. This occurs due to the increase in anthropogenic emissions of carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) in the atmosphere. The higher the concentration of atmospheric CO 2 , the greater the concentration of CO in the ocean due to the diffusional balance between the atmosphere and the oceanic compartments (Feely et al., 2009) . One third of all CO 2 released into the atmosphere is incorporated into the oceans and this is favored by its high solubility in water (Sabine et al., 2004) . With the beginning of the industrial revolution, the atmospheric concentration of CO 2 increased from approximately 280 to 390 ppm (Feely et al., 2009) . Currently, researches conducted by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), indicates that atmospheric CO 2 concentrations will be between 750 and ppm by the end of this century (IPCC, 2014) . Based on this, it is estimated that the pH of the oceans may decrease from 8.1 to 7.6 in the same period (Feely et al., 2009; Doney et al., 2009) .

In recent decades, the process of ocean acidification has drawn attention because of the damage that it causes to marine organisms. In the oceans, an increased CO 2 level causes an increase in H + ions and a reduction in carbonate concentrations (CO 3 2− ), which is used to buffer H + to prevent decreases in pH. The decrease in CO 3 2− concentration reduces the calcium carbonate (CaCO ) saturation state, directly affecting organisms that depend on this compound to produce their shells or skeletons (Orr, 2011; Andersson and Gledhill, 2013) . When the CO 2 concentration exceeds the buffering capacity of water, the pH inevitably decreases. Some effects of ocean acidification have been studied experimentally in calcifying organisms. For example, in bivalve mollusks, including Mercenaria mercenaria, Crassostrea virginica, and Argopecten irradians, survival, development, growth, and lipid synthesis during the larval stage were reduced with the increase in water temperature and CO 2 concentration (Talmage and Gobler, 2011) . Alterations in the growth of calcifying organisms may be associated with activities of the Ca 2+ -ATPase and carbonic anhydrase (CA) enzymes. The Ca 2+ -ATPase captures and transports calcium ions to calcification sites (Zebral et al., 2019) , while CA catalyzes the hydration of CO 2 , resulting in the formation of H + and HCO 3 − . The complexation of HCO 3 − with calcium forms CaCO 3 which is deposited in the shell for growth (Jorge et al., 2016; Zebral et al., 2019) . Conversely, acidification can alter the redox state of an organism, and in this respect, antioxidant enzymes may indicate the stress. Matozzo et al. (2013) observed an increase in the activity of the antioxidant enzymes superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT) and glutathione S-transferase (GST) in the bivalves Chamelea gallina and Mytilus gallaprovincialis exposed to low pHs (7.7 and 7.4). Authors related the increase in antioxidants defenses to a decrease in lipid peroxidation (LPO), a well-established signal of oxidative stress. Ecotoxicological researches conducted with bivalve mollusks have shown their ability to accumulate organic contaminants, including UV filters (Sang and Leung, 2016; Peng et al., 2017) . Bivalves are considered as excellent sentinel species for environmental contamination because they are sessile, filter feeders and relatively tolerant to several compounds. Additionally, they have great ecological and economic importance. The yellow clam, Amarilladesma mactroides, is a marine bivalve suspension-feeder, inhabiting sandy beaches over the southern coast of Brazil and coasts of Uruguay and Argentina (Herrmann et al., 2011) . There are several studies that show the relevance of A. mactroides as a model for toxicological evaluations, including those that use biomarkers as tools to assess toxicity of chemicals (Giacomin et al., 2014; Nogueira et al., 2013; Jorge et al., 2016) .

Among biochemical biomarkers, measures of antioxidants and molecular damages have been shown to be suitable to determine toxic effects of a wide spectrum of compounds. In this sense, GST participates in antioxidant defense, neutralizing products of LPO and conjugating xenobiotics with reduced glutathione (GSH). Conjugation with GSH makes the xenobiotic less reactive and more soluble for excretion. GSH is also part of non-enzymatic antioxidant defense as it can interact directly with oxidative molecules. Glutamate cysteine ligase (GCL) catalyzes the binding of amino acids, glutamate and cysteine, for the further formation of GSH; while LPO is a measurement of oxidative cellular damage (Hermes-Lima, 2004) . Biomarkers other than those involved in antioxidant defense or biotransformation can be also affected by the presence of pollutant and adverse conditions such as acidification. In this context, activities of the CA and Ca 2+ -ATPase enzymes are considered as feasible biomarkers for calcifying organisms in face of acidification.

Take into account the backgrounds exposed above, this work aimed to evaluate the isolated and combined effects of two environmental stressors, ocean acidification and BP3 contamination, on biochemical biomarkers of A. mactroides [GST, GCL, GSH, LPO, CA and Ca 2+ -ATPase]. For that, it was chosen tissues with different physiological roles as gills, liver and mantle. Because gills are the interface between the animal and water, they are an important entry route of environmental contaminants; the digestive gland is the main organ used for detoxification; and the mantle was chosen due to its greatly involved in shell mineralization/synthesis.

Adults of A. mactroides (shell length = 5.14 ± 0.16 cm) were collected manually (License for capture: SISBIO 58034-1) at Mar Grosso beach in São José do Norte, southern Brazil. They were acclimated for one week in the Animal Care Room of the Institute of Biological Sciences of the Federal University of Rio Grande. Clams were maintained in a continuously aerated 20 L aquarium filled with natural seawater that had a salinity of 30. Room temperature was maintained at 20°C with a photoperiod of 12 h of light and 12 h of darkness. The pH over acclimation was kept at pH 8.1 (pH of natural seawater). Animals were fed 3 times a week with microalgae, Nannochloropsis sp. After feeding, water was completely renewed in each aquarium.

Experiments were performed in artificial saltwater (salinity 30) prepared by mixing marine salt (Instant Ocean®) with water obtained from a reverse osmosis system (Millipore®). Saltwater was prepared at least 24 h prior to the start of an experiment for chemical stabilization. During this time, water was continuously aerated to facilitate salt solubilization. The desired salinity was checked using a refractometer (Atago, Brazil). BP3 (99% purity) used for water contamination was commercially obtained from a compounding pharmacy (BOTICA -Farmácia de manipulação, CNPJ-04.508.808/0001-35). BP3 was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (100%) at 10 mg/L and this solution, named as working solution, was then added to the aquariums immediately before clam addition at a final concentration of 1 μg/L of BP3 and 0.01% DMSO. Due to the low solubility of BP3 in water, we used DMSO as a vehicle to dissolve this compound. DMSO is one of the most widely used vehicle in in vivo and in vitro experiments due to its "low" toxicity when compared to other solvents such as acetone. The concentration of 0.01% of solvent is the maximum concentration recommended in guidelines for testing toxicity of chemicals (OECD 121, 2010). In addition, many studies that evaluated the effects of BP3 on aquatic organisms used DMSO as solvent (Gao et al., 2013; Liu et al., 2015; Downs et al., 2016) . It is worth saying that BP3 reach environment as a compound of sunscreens that contain emulsifiers in their formulas. This facilitates the dissolution of BP3 and other lipophilic chemicals in natural waters.

Acclimated clams were divided into 6 groups: (1) control at pH 8.1, (2) vehicle at pH 8.1, (3) exposed to 1 μg/L BP3 at pH 8.1, (4) control at pH 7.6, (5) vehicle at pH 7.6, (6) exposed to 1 μg/L BP3 at pH 7.6. The concentration of BP3 was chosen for its environmental relevance to marine environments. pH 8.1 is considered a natural pH for seawater and it was the pH at which clams were acclimated, while pH 7.6 is the predicted pH for oceans in 2100 (IPCC, 2014). Concentration of 0.01% DMSO was kept in all experimental groups. Twelve animals per treatment were used and were divided into 3 replicates with 4 animals each. For each replicate, the clams were placed in an aquarium containing 5 L of water. Experiments lasted 96 h, with media renewal 48 h after feeding with microalgae. Water samples were collected from each aquarium at the beginning of the experiment for BP3 quantification (250 mL) and alkalinity measurements (50 mL). At the end of the experiments, clams were cryoanesthetized and their tissues (gills, digestive gland, and mantle) were removed and stored at -80°C for biochemical analysis.

To keep the pH level consistent throughout the experiment, we used an automated CO 2 injection system (Altamar Aquatic Systems®, Brazil). This system seeks to provide a laboratory-based simulation of the acidification process in the marine environment, by CO 2 leaks during the carbon dioxide capture and storage process. The desired pH was reached through CO 2 injection in the seawater from a CO 2 cylinder. To regulate pH throughout the experiment, pH probes were connected to the system (immersed in the aquariums). When pH increased, solenoid valves connected to the CO 2 cylinder opened and gas was injected into the water until the pH reached 7.6. Artificial seawater had pH 8.1. During the experiment, the pH of each aquarium was automatically monitored every 10 min but recorded only twice a day (see Supplementary material).

Total alkalinity was determined using the titrimetric method described by the American Public Health Association (APHA, 1989) . A pHmeter (Hanna Instruments, Woonsocket, RI, USA) was used to measure the pH of water samples in the alkalinity assay. The values of pH, alkalinity, temperature, and salinity were used to calculate the parameters of the seawater carbonate system by the CO2SYS program (Pierrot et al., 2006) .

The analytical method applied for BP3 measurement was based on Lempart et al. (2018) with modifications. BP3 was analyzed in water samples collected from experimental media. A sample volume of 250 mL of saltwater from each aquarium was taken and filtered using 0.47 μm fiberglass membrane filters. The BP3 compound was extracted from saltwater by solid phase extraction (SPE). C18 cartridges (500 mg, 6 mL) (Supelco, Sigma Aldrich®, Brazil) were previously activated with 5 mL methanol (HPLC grade), 5 mL acetonitrile (HPLC grade), and 5 mL of ultrapure water. In solid phase extraction (SPE), the sample was preconcentrated in 125 times (250 mL to 2 mL). After BP3 extraction, 10 mL of ultrapure water was percolated in the cartridges to remove excess salt and were then dried with a vacuum pump and stored at 4°C for further analysis. To quantify BP3, the cartridges were eluted with 1 mL of methanol and 1 mL of acetonitrile. The extracts were analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography coupled to a diode array detector (HPLC-DAD). The HPLC system was composed of a Waters 600 pump model, associated with a Waters 2996 Photodiode Array Detector, a Rheodyne 20 μL loop injector, and connected to an Empower PDA software for data acquisition. The analytical column used was a Synergi Fusion 4 μm (250 × 4.6 mm). The mobile phase was composed of acetonitrile and ultrapure water at pH 3, (70:30, v/v). The instrumental limit of detection (LOD) was 15 µg/L and the instrumental limit of quantification (LOQ) was 50 µg/L. BP3 (purity grade > 99%) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich®, Brazil.

The gills, digestive gland, and mantle from 6 clams were thawed on ice and homogenized in GCL homogenization buffer (100 mM Tris-HCl, 2 mM EDTA, and 5 mM MgCl 2.6H 2 O; pH 7.75) using a manual homogenizer, in a ratio of 1:5 weight/volume (w/v) for gland and gills and 1:3 w/v for mantle. Tissue homogenates where then centrifuged at 10,000 ×g at 4°C for 20 min. The supernatants were used to determine GST and GCL activity and GSH and LPO levels. Those measurements were standardized by protein content in the supernatant, which was determined by the biuret method (commercial kit Doles®, Brazil).

GST activity was determined using the method described by Keen et al. (1976) , which consists of catalyzing the GST to conjugate GSH with 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene (CDNB). Briefly, 10 μL of sample was incubated with a phosphate buffer (100 mM KH 2 PO 4 ) containing CDNB (0.77 mM) and GSH (1 mM) and absorbance was measured at 340 nm in a microplate reader (Elx880, BioTeK instruments Winooski, VT, USA). GSH levels and GCL activity were determined in the same assay using methodology by White et al. (2003) . This method is based on the reaction of 2,3-naphthalenedicarboxaldehyde (NDA) with GSH, forming γ-Glu-Cys that generates fluorescence. This reaction indicates GCL activity by the amount of fluorescence. To detect basal GSH levels, no cysteine was added to the GSH plate and the plate was kept on ice. The fluorescence of the complexes was measured using a fluorometer (Victor 2 ™ Multilabel Counter model 1420-051, Turku, Finland) at 472 nm (excitation) and 528 nm (emission).

LPO levels were measured using the TBARS Assay Kit (Cayman Chemical® No.10009055). It quantifies the level of malondialdehyde (MDA), one of the products of lipid peroxidation. MDA reacts with thiobarbituric acid, which at high temperature generates a chromogen. This was measured by spectrofluorimetry at 530 nm (excitation) and 555 nm (emission).

Tissues dissected from the remaining 6 clams were thawed on ice and then homogenized in a buffer containing 75 mM sucrose, 10 mM tris-base, 1 mM phenyl methanesulfonyl fluoride (PMSF), and 1 mM dithiothreitol (DTT). The pH was adjusted to 8.5 and was mixed in a ratio of 1:4 w/v for gland and gills and 1:3 w/v for mantle. The homogenates were centrifuged at 20,000 ×g, 4°C for 20 min. The activity of each of the enzymes, CA and Ca 2+ -ATPase, were analyzed separately in the supernatant (Nogueira et al., 2018) . As described above, these measures were standardized by the amount of protein in the supernatant, which was quantified by the biuret method.

CA activity was determined using the method described by Henry (1991) . Briefly, 10 μL of the supernatant from each tissue was mixed to 3 mL of the reaction buffer (10 mM Tris-base, 75 mM sucrose, 225 mM mannitol, and 10 mM sodium phosphate; pH 8.5) and added to 390 μL of saturated CO 2 ultrapure water. Enzyme activity was determined by reducing the pH in the reaction mixture, which was monitored every 5 s for 30 s, using a pHmeter (Hanna Instruments, Woonsocket, RI, USA). The CA is responsible for the hydration of CO 2 and, consequently, for the release of H + ions. The greater the drop in pH, the greater the activity of CA. Ca 2+ -ATPase activity was determined by the colorimetric method described by Vajreswari et al. (1983) with adaptations. An aliquot of 10 μL of the homogenate was added to a reaction buffer (5 mM CaCl 2 , 5 mM MgCl 2 , 20 mM Tris-HCl, and 189 mM NaCl; pH 7.6 with and without 1 mM ouabaine and 3 mM ATP) in microtubes and incubated at 30°C for 30 min to allow the enzymatic reaction to occur. Microtubes were then placed on ice to stop the reaction. The amount of inorganic phosphate released into the reaction mixture was determined using a phosphate colorimetric assay kit (MAK030, Sigma-Aldrich). Absorbance was measured at 630 nm on the microplate reader (Elx880 BioTeK instruments Winooski, VT, USA).

Results are expressed as the mean ± standard error. For statistical analysis, two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Newman-Keuls post-hoc test was used to compare BP3 treatments and pH. When necessary, data were log-transformed to meet ANOVA assumptions. The assumptions of normality and homoscedasticity were previously verified by the Shapiro-Wilk and Levene tests, respectively. The adopted significance level was 95% (α = 0.05).

The concentration of BP3 in control groups, with and without the vehicle, regardless of the pH tested, was below LOD, while the average BP3 concentration in contaminated waters was 0.20 ± 0.03 μg/L. Alkalinity and carbonate speciation varied significantly between treatments at pH 8.1 and 7.6 ( Table 1) . The temperature and pH values were recorded throughout the experiment and had little variation (see Supplementary material). As CO 2 concentration increased, the carbonate (CO 3 2− ) saturation state decreased, thereby reducing the levels of calcium carbonate (CaCO 3 ) saturation (Table 1) .

GST activity increased in the gills and decreased in the mantle of clams exposed to lower pH (7.6), but pH did not affect the GST activity in the digestive gland ( Fig. 1) . At pH 8.1, BP3 significantly increased GST activity in the digestive gland. Additionally, levels of GST activity were similar in the gills and digestive gland, but were 10-fold lower in the mantle.

The pH 7.6 stimulated GCL activity in the gills, however, at this pH, BP3 inhibited GCL activity compared to the control groups ( Fig. 2A) . In the digestive gland, at pH 8.1, GCL activity was much lower in the vehicle and BP3 exposed clams and no significant difference was found between these two groups. Dissimilarity, at pH 7.6, GCL activity was augmented in the vehicle and BP3 exposure group when compared to the control without the vehicle. The pH only affected control groups without vehicle; at pH 8.1, the GCL activity was higher than at pH 7.6 ( Fig. 2B ). In the mantle tissue, GCL activity was not affected by pH or BP3 (Fig. 1C) . In the digestive gland of control clams, mean GCL activity was higher than in the mantle which, in turn, was greater than in the gills. At pH 7.6, the concentration of GSH in gills significantly increased when clams were exposed to BP3 (Fig. 3A) . On the other hand, in digestive gland, the GSH concentration of was lower in treatments with the vehicle and BP3 for the pH 8.1 (Fig. 3B ). Mantle GSH concentrations increased at pH 7.6 in control groups (with and without vehicle) when compared to the same treatments at pH 8.1, while BP3 caused a decrease in GSH levels compared to controls at pH 7.6 ( Fig. 3C) . No effect Fig. 1 . Gluthathione-S-Tranferase (GST) activity measured in the gills (A), digestive gland (B), and mantle (C) of Amarilladesma mactroides under different treatment conditions: control, vehicle (0.01% DMSO), and exposed to 1 μg/L Benzophenone-3 for 96 h. Data are expressed as mean ± standard error. Capital letters indicate significant differences between treatments for each pH. Lowercase letters indicate significant differences between pH 8.1 and 7.6 (p < 0.05). of BP3 or pH was observed on LPO levels in gills and digestive gland ( Fig. 4A and B, respectively) . Conversely, the LPO concentration was reduced in the mantle for treatments with vehicle and BP3 at pH 8.1. These groups were significantly different from each other. In addition, LPO levels were lower in control and vehicle treatments at pH 7.6 when compared to the same treatments at pH 8.1 (Fig. 4C) . CA activity was augmented in the gills of clams exposed to the vehicle and BP3 at pH 8.1, but there was no difference between treatments at pH 7.6. CA activity was significantly lower in the gill tissue of clams exposed to BP3 at pH 7.6 compared to the same treatments at pH 8.1 (Fig. 5A ). In the digestive gland, BP3 augmented CA activity at both pH levels, but less so at pH 7.6 ( Fig. 5B) . For the mantle, there was no statistical difference between treatments (Fig. 5C ).

Ca 2+ -ATPase activity in the gills of clams exposed to pH 7.6 was greater than that of animals submitted to experiments at pH 8.1, but there were no differences between treatments for both pH tested (Fig. 6A) . In contrast, in the digestive gland, Ca 2+ -ATPase activity was higher at pH 8.1 than at pH 7.6, also without significant difference between treatments (Fig. 6B) . No statistical differences on Ca 2+ -ATPase activity were observed in mantle tissues, regardless the pH (Fig. 6C) .

This study showed the ability of 1 μg/L of BP3 exposure to modulate GST and GCL activities, as well as altering GSH levels in A. mactroides tissues (Fig. 1, Fig. 2, and Fig. 3, respectively) . Although these alterations in antioxidants state, the exposure of BP3 at this environmental concentration was not capable of affecting the LPO status in gills, digestive gland, or mantle after short-term exposure (96 h) (Fig. 4) . LPO was the only oxidative damage chosen to be analyzed in this study; however it is not wise to discard that other kind of oxidative injury, such as in nucleic acids or proteins might have occurred; as was observed by Downs et al. (2016) , who evidenced the capability of BP3 causing DNA damage in corals. Moreover, it is worth saying that besides BP3 effects, it was also considered for results interpretation, the effects caused by the 'vehicle' (DMSO) used to dissolve BP3 in water.

BP3 is capable of being accumulated by the marine biota as several studies demonstrated; however, this potential is lower when compared to other UV filters such as ethylhexyl methoxycinnamate (EHMC) (Gago-Ferrero et al., 2015; Langford et al., 2015; Sang and Leung, 2016; Vidal-Liñán et al., 2018) . Concentrations of BP3 up to 12.4 ng/g dry weight (dw) were reported in mussels inhabiting Hong Kong coastal waters by Sang and Leung (2016) . The authors also detected one of the main metabolites of BP3, the Benzophenone-8 (BP8) compound, which seems to be more easily bioaccumulative than BP3, possible, due to its higher Log Kow (4.31 for BP8 and 3.79 for BP3). Meanwhile, in Spain waters Rodil et al. (2019) reported 63 ng/g dw BP3 as the maximum concentration observed in marine bilvalves from the Galician coast, while in Almuñecar, Martín et al. (2017) described a concentration of 53.9 ng/g dw BP3 in the sea cucumber Holothuria tubulosa; however, later Martín et al., (2020) indicated that BP3 is "non accumulative" to H. tubulosa due to its low value bioconcentration factor, this factor calculated by them. Regarding the time necessary for the uptake and bioaccumulation of BP3 Vidal-Liñán et al. (2018) reported this occurs rapidly by M. galloprovincialis, however BP3 it is also promptly metabolized by the mussels, approximately in 1 to 2 days. This study also Fig. 2 . Data are expressed as mean ± standard error. Capital letters indicate significant differences between treatments for each pH. Lowercase letters indicate significant differences between pH 8.1 and 7.6 (p < 0.05).
shown that BP3 metabolization is higher than benzophenone 4 (BP4) and octocrylene (OC), similar compounds.

It has been indicated that BP3 has the ability of activate biotransformation process in fish and aquatic invertebrates towards to its own elimination (Blüthgen et al., 2012; Vidal-Liñán et al., 2018; He et al., 2019) . Also, it was evidenced in different groups of organisms, that BP3 have the capacity of activating their antioxidant defense system, these including enzymes such as superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), GST, and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) (Gao et al., 2013; Liu et al., 2015; Rodríguez-Fuentes et al., 2015; Muñiz-González and Martínez-Guitarte, 2020) . The lower activity of GCL observed in gills of clams exposed to BP3 at pH 7.6, associated with the GSH increase (Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, respectively) , suggests that BP3 induced the GCL activity for an increase in the GSH synthesis within the 96 h of the experiment, as was observed in the GSH total concentration. However, as the time passed towards the end of the 96 h, probably the BP3 reduced the activity of this enzyme, leading to a later decrease in GSH levels. In a similar way, Huang et al. (2018) observed an increase in GSH levels in the gills of Mytilus coruscus exposed to nanoparticles of titanium dioxide (nano-TiO2 at 10 mg/L) for 24 h at pH 8.1 and 7.3; and after 3 days, GSH levels started to decrease at the pH 7.3. Another point to consider is that GSH is a competitive inhibitor of GCL and when the levels of GSH are very high, GCL can be inhibited as a negative feedback mechanism (Hermes-Lima, 2004) . Regardless of the pathways that led to a decrease in GCL activity, this situation only occurred under acidification, indicating that animals at pH 7.6 could be more susceptible to the effects of BP3. However, we must remember that there was an increase in the activity of GST in the gills of clams under conditions of acidification, thus stimulating a response for general protection. In all treatments, LPO levels were not increased in the gills (Fig. 1 and  Fig. 4, respectively) , indicating that gills may cope with acute exposure to BP3, even at pH 7.6.

For the digestive gland, there was no effect of BP3 on GCL activity and GSH concentration based on significantly differences between BP3 and vehicle treatments, however, BP3 increased GST activity at pH 8.1. This may happen in order to promote detoxification of BP3 and might have prevented an increase in LPO concentration in the digestive gland. Liu et al. (2015) also detected an increase in the GST activity in liver of goldfish Carassius auratus exposed to 0.5 and 5 mg/L of BP3, however, in contrast to our results it was reported an increase in GSH concentration as well. The authors suggested that GST is involved in the biotransformation of BP3 and, thus, in the formation of GSH-BP3 complexes for BP3 elimination. Although, it is important to consider that concentrations of BP3 used by Liu et al. (2015) were higher than those used in this study. Moreover, the lack of reaction by GST in the digestive gland of organisms exposed to BP3 at pH 7.6, compared to an increase in activity at pH 8.1, reinforces a possible failure in detoxification responses in the face of acidification.

Decreased levels of GSH following clam exposure to BP3, at pH 7.6, were observed in mantle tissue. This could indicate that GSH is being consumed for BP3 detoxification, since it was not accompanied by a decrease in GCL activity, which did not change regardless of the treatment or the pH tested. In addition, despite the higher levels of GSH in the mantle tissues of control clams at pH 7.6, there was a reduction in Fig. 3 . Data are expressed as mean ± standard error. Capital letters indicate significant differences between treatments for each pH. Lowercase letters indicate significant differences between pH 8.1 and 7.6 (p < 0.05).

GST activity. This suggests that acidification reduces the mantle detoxification ability; however, like other tissues, a reflection in the LPO concentration was not observed. Similarly, Liao et al. (2019) did not observe variations in the antioxidants SOD and CAT or increases in ROS and LPO concentrations in the mantle of the Yesso scallop Patinopecten yessoensis after exposure (45 days) to pH 7.5; however, the authors found and increase in Na + /K + -ATPase activity accompanied by a decrease in ATP content. Probably because the mantle has a high activity of ATPases (e.g. Na + /K + -ATPase, Ca 2+ -ATPase and H + -ATPase), and CA due to its role in shell mineralization and acid-base balance (Marin et al., 2012; Liao et al., 2019) .

Ca 2+ -ATPase was affected only by exposure to pH 7.6 in gills and digestive gland of clams. Despite the mantle role in the shell mineralization of mollusks (Fan et al., 2007; Marin et al., 2012; Zhang et al., 2019) , we did not observe any effects of pH or BP3 on Ca 2+ -ATPase activity in this tissue (Fig. 5 ). This enzyme is directly involved in calcium uptake needed for shell formation; however, shell mineralization does not depend only on calcium but also on the availability of carbonated species to form aragonite or calcite, which, in turn, is directly related to environmental pH (lower pH, lower concentration of carbonated species) (Marin et al., 2012) . Hüning et al. (2013) also found no relationship between acidification and gene expression associated with Ca 2+ -ATPase in the mantle of Mytilus edulis, submitted to elevated concentrations of pCO 2 in water (pH 8.03, 7.7, 7.38, 7. 14; 2 months of exposure). This result could be explained by the fact that there are proteins, other than Ca 2+ -ATPase, that participate in the process of calcium uptake and release by the mantle (Li et al., 2004; Liu et al., 2012) . Besides, gills are the tissue that is considered the main organ responsible for capturing calcium ions from the external environment (Fan et al., 2007; Zhang et al., 2019) . Thus, the increase in Ca 2+ -AT-Pase in gills of clams exposed to pH 7.6, in comparison to pH 8.1 (Fig. 5 ), might be associated with an attempt by the animal to replenish or maintain its calcium stores due to the possibility of demineralization at low pH. Moreover, despite that the digestive gland is not an organ directly involved in Ca 2+ uptake (Fan et al., 2007) , it needs Ca 2+ for cellular physiological processes (Marigómez et al., 2002) . Therefore, at pH 7.6, a decrease in the activity of Ca 2+ -ATPase in the digestive gland would be harmful to homeostasis, ultimately affecting its role in detoxifying xenobiotics.

BP3 affected the CA activity in gills and digestive gland, the same was not observed in mantle though. The decreased levels of CA activity in the gills of animals exposed to BP3 at pH 7.6, compared to the same treatment at pH 8.1, raise the concern of BP3 harming the shell mineralization, ionic and osmotic regulation and acid-basic balance, since these processes depend on branchial CA activity in clams (Jorge et al., 2016; Roberto et al., 2010; Fonseca et al., 2019) . In the digestive gland, the greater effect of BP3 at pH 8.1, inducing CA activity, when compared to pH 7.6, suggests that the response of the digestive gland to BP3 is suppressed by acidification. Besides, other studies have shown that CA activity decreased after exposure low pH conditions. Moreira et al. (2016) described this phenomenon in C. gigas and Crassostrea angulata, two oyster species exposed (28 days) to pH 7.3, while Marangoni et al. (2019) observed the similar effect in Mussismilia harttii, a coral specie, exposed (15 and 35 days) to pH 7.5 and 7.2. Fig. 4 . Lipoperoxidation (LPO) measured in the gills (A), digestive gland (B) and mantle (C) of Amarilladesma mactroides under different treatment conditions: control, vehicle (0.01% DMSO), and exposed to 1 μg/L Benzophenone-3 for 96 h. Data are expressed as mean ± standard error. Capital letters indicate significant differences between treatments for each pH. Lowercase letters indicate significant differences between pH 8.1 and 7.6 (p < 0.05).

Our results indicate that an environmentally relevant concentration of 1 μg/L of BP3 can alter biochemical biomarkers, including the GSH concentration and GCL and GST activities in the gills, digestive gland, and mantle. Additionally, these biomarkers can be changed by creating an acidification scenario and decreasing the detoxification ability of animals when they are under lower pH conditions. However, we observed no alterations in LPO concentration, suggesting that the tissues analyzed are able to deal with these stressors, BP3 and acidification, after acute exposure and in terms of lipid oxidation. Variations in Ca 2+ -ATPase indicate that this enzyme can be affected by acidification but does not seem to be a target of BP3, at least at 1 μg/L. However, CA activity was affected by pH and BP3, demonstrating that the risk of ocean acidification and pollution by BP3 is a concern for calcifying organisms, such as the yellow clam A. mactroides. Finally, it is clear that each tissue responded in its own way to BP3, but the gills and digestive gland were more sensitive to this contaminant than mantle.
